content: it's like regular painting just more dry [Applause]
hey guys welcome back to another episode of black magic crafts got another basics
video for you guys I didn't think I'd be able to make a video for you guys this
week because I hella sick lost my voice completely and we have to go out of town
for the weekend that I would normally film on but I managed to regain my voice
I still feel like crap and I'm managing to squeeze in some filming time on a
weeknight so today I am going to cover what is a very simple technique but it's
probably one of the most fundamental and most important painting techniques for
any terrain builder dry-brushing a strain builders we live and die by the
dry brush dry brushing and washes is what make your pieces look awesome
and you can get by without the washes but you really can't get by without the
dry brushing you need to get this technique down luckily it's a pretty
damn easy technique to understand and learn and do but like anything if you're
really new to the Hobby and people just start talking about it it can seem a
little bit overwhelming and there are a few kind of simple mistakes that people
tend to make when just starting out so I'm going to show you how to dry brush
and what to avoid when starting out and you should be good to go and then we can
move on to more complicated techniques so let's zoom into the workbench and
let's quickly dry brush up a little piece of train so here I have a little
rock that I carved up covered in black Mod Podge and
painted one coat of a dark grey not much to it but it has a lot of detail and
edges to pick up the dry brushing and that is the whole point of dry brushing
essentially is to highlight all of the high points on your piece and add a lot
of depth so that it looks three-dimensional instead of flat and
boring generally dry brushing is not the first step in painting often you're
going to want to do a base coat in a color or a few colors depending on what
it is you're painting if you're painting a building you generally want to paint
out the stone in the wood and the different features in their primary
color and then use the dry brushing to do your highlights and you can use dry
brushing to add as many burying layers as you want slowly working from darkest
to lightest and mixing in different color tones and the more you do the more
depth or pieces going to have when you're doing something like natural
stone if you do several different layers mixing in different greens yellows and
browns it's only going to add to the effect however for most things like
dungeon tiles and stone work especially if you're just starting out you can get
away with just you know two or three shades of gray often just actually one
shade of dark gray and then one dry brushing of light gray and you can call
it done and put it on your table and I'm going to show you just two different
shades here to get you started and then once you have the technique down you can
experiment and go from there so rock is covered with its gray coat and I'm going
to take some you know cheap acrylic craft paint in a grey that is lighter
obviously you can achieve lighter shades by mixing with white or you can be lazy
like me and just buy a few different shades of grey so to start I'm just
going to put a little bit of paint a paper towel here keep in mind you
don't need very much paint when you're dry brushing because the whole idea is
to put on a small amount of paint I like to take a fairly large brush we own
usually three quarter inch or an inch wide and this is a great place to use
you're kind of Haggard and old crappy brushes that are starting to get frayed
because dry brushing will abuse them and also it doesn't matter for this
application how nice the brush is so want to take your brush and load up
paint on both sides that's quite a bit of paint there but the first thing
you're going to do is wipe it all off and when I say all I mean like 98% of it
when you're wiping it on the paper towel if it is covering a solid line of color
on the paper towel you have too much paint on your brush it should get to a
point where only a little bit of the paint is hitting the high spots of your
paper towel and whatever textures on the towel becomes highlighted and the low
points don't take any paint you can also test it on your hand and if running it
across your hand starts to highlight your skin pattern and only hits the top
surface and doesn't really color your hand too much you know you're in the
right territory it feels like the brush is wet on your hand then you have too
much paint the most important lesson with dry brushing is you can always add
more but it is very difficult to remove when you have too much if you start
trying to do this and you have too much paint on your brush you're going to get
splotches and heavy spots that there's really no way to correct without
completely repainting so always err on the side of caution and use little
amounts of paint and if you feel like it's not putting enough on the piece
then load your brush with more start with less so then once you have
your brush unloaded pretty much all you're going to do is lightly go across
the piece and just go from different directions and try to just hit the high
points what you're trying to do is pull out texture and when you are working on
a piece I like to think that a piece has two texture points and loop let's put
this here I like to think that a piece has two texture points and what I mean
by that is a piece will have high ridge high impact textures like high points on
these stones and low detail texture on safe the flat surfaces so these ridges
are like the high detail and the flat surface will still have low detail
texture and you can see as I'm brushing across it starts to bring out some of
that low detail while also hitting the high details and if you're going to be
doing a two-toned dry brushing let's say a light gray and then a bright gray or a
white the first coat of dry brushing you essentially want to pull out both high
and low detail as much as possible and the thing is when you're brushing and
you're getting that lower detail by default you're going to get the higher
detail and what's going to happen is by trying to get the flat work texture you
are going to over dry brush these high ridges and they are going to pop out
even more so that's why you kind of need to do this stuff in a two-stage process
so that you can you know add a little bit of subtlety to what you're doing and
you can see I'm not like right now I'm actually not even looking at this
looking at the camera because with a bit of practice you know what it you can't
really screw it up essentially the only way you can screw this up
is if you have too much paint on your brush otherwise you you are going to be
completely fine so I have this to a point where I am happy with it already
the piece is starting to have a lot more depth and if it were sitting on a table
it would pop out a lot more now I did this entire piece with one brush load
right I never put my brush back in the paint obviously if you're doing a bigger
piece you're going to have to reload your brush and what I like to do is on
my first one I load it in the you know dab of paint and then I brush it out
onto the paper towel now when I go to reload my brush I won't go back to that
main area of paint I'm going to take this spot here where it unloaded paint
from the first time and reload from there that way I avoid over filling my
brush again and having to brush out that much paint this way it adds a little bit
more brush or this way it adds a little bit more paint to my brush without you
know over saturating it and I can go back in do some more dry brushing and I
can again load up and each time it's going to give you a little bit less
paint you have to unload a little less and then depending on how many pieces
you're doing or how big of a piece this will eventually dry out and you'll start
the process again with you know fresh paint unload and go from there so that's
your first coat dry bearing that's it that's all there is to it it's really
pretty simple essentially you have a brush that has a very small amount of
paint on it to the point of the brush being dry and you're just lightly going
over it you want to think of it like you're not painting the piece but you're
powdering it you want your brush just have like a layer of
powder and with this acrylic paint it dries fast so it actually does dry out
on the bristles and you're doing this and you are painting literally with dry
paint now if you want to take things up step further go up to a lighter shade
and however many you want to do is great but I like to end almost every piece
with it and almost white I don't use a bright way I use like a vanilla or a
bone or a cream and I like to use this just to get the very the very high
points on a piece and really highlight them so here I'm going to use even less
paint than the first time and you'll notice I didn't clean my brush in
between or dip it any water because you don't want to dip this brush in water as
your dry brushing otherwise it's going to be really hard to unload it to a
point where it's you know you have a small enough amount of paint on it to to
accomplish dry brush and keep your brush dry I'm going to say dry a lot in this
video I like my damn throat also because I didn't wash it the white is kind of
blending with the gray that I already had in there and that's fine it's just
going to make the transitions between your coat more subtle so now when you
get to your last stage of dry brushing with your white this one you are going
to be very cautious with especially starting out just to lightly go across
because you don't want to overdo it with this go lightly get a feel for how much
paint is on your brush and once you start to get comfortable with the amount
of paint that's on there you can go a little bit more aggressively like the
last one keep it subtle and because almost every piece I make gets a black
wash to finish it off I tend to make my dry brushing a little bit more extreme I
want the piece to almost cool so if you're not going to do a black
wash don't over do this because it will make the piece look like it's shining
bright light with this much white on the edges but black wash is going to mute
everything so keep that in mind and experiment but that's it every stage of
dry brushing do a little bit less if you're going to do five shades of grey
each time you do the next one use a little bit less paint on your brush and
cover a little bit less of the surface so that areas that are recessed may when
we get the first or second color and as the depth works out on the piece it ends
with just the very highest point getting the brightest color I recommend making
some little scrap pieces of you know terrain to work with and you'll carve up
some little rocks use some scrap material whatever and just practice on
it and once you feel comfortable with unloading the brush and knowing when it
feels right then you will be set for life with dry brushing and you will only
get better at it the more you practice that's it there you go no big deal real
easy technique now you know what to do you just need a bit of practice and you
will be good to go of course if you found this video useful hit that like
button if you aren't already a subscriber hit subscribe if you've got
any more questions or things you might need help with drop me a comment below
or head over to the black magic craft Facebook page and drop me a comment
